content.description: From the small block in the corner move up a move then out onto the very steep face. Just one or two moves and you are at the top.
content.protection: TR from steel anchor or trees. Has been bouldered but is definitely highball.
content.location:
On the north facing wall with Midnight Lightning. On your left halfway down as you approach the main face. 

  Start in the corner on the left on top of the small block.

content.description:
Start on a rail with your feet under the bulge. Climb the initial bulge and continue up the technical face and incipient crack to the upper crux bulge. Move slightly right and up and over then continue to the top. You should still be left of the roof proper.  

  Great technical face climbing. Wait for cool temps to make sure that the grease factor does not play a huge role. 

  There used to a bolt on top, but it is long gone.
content.location: Start on the small rail under a bulge just to the right of Beginners Corner Sometimes the feet here are muddy and need a quick scrubbing.

content.description: Begin standing at the far right of the lip on the west side of the boulder.  Hand traverse out the horizontal lip, turn the corner of the boulder to finish on the white vertical northf ace (Mike's Move V0-) without using the arete.
content.location: The boulder to climber's left of the Ilchester cliff

content.description: Stand start on the vertical face. Top out at the tallest part of the boulder.
content.location: On the vertical face of the lone boulder climbers left of the cliff face.

content.description:
Start on two crimps and crank straight up to a decent hold, before moving up and slightly left to the top. 

  Tough first move has been made tougher due to recent graffiti, and the steep top face isnt getting any easier either.
content.location: Start in the center of the face.

content.description:
Climbs the main, wide-ish crack/layback in the middle of the face. Hence the name. Steepens a bit at the top. 

  A popular intro to the area, and a good one to get used to the slightly strange rock at Ilchester. 

  Start is the crux no matter how you start.
content.protection:
As long as someone spots you off the ground, this quickly becomes G rated gear. TR anchor on top. 

  Can seep a bit after the rain.
content.location: Many starts for this ranging from using the tree to go straight up, to variations right and left. Watch swing if starting to the side.

content.description: The classic mantel move. Start on the lip/rail and mantel onto the slab above.
The Crux is pulling through the roof using the 2 o shaped finger pockets that the route is named for.
content.location: While facing the Illchester with the tree behind you look to the right and start on the large flake about eye level move up and to the under-cling at the base of the overhang. Pull through the overhang via o shaped finger pockets that the climb is named for. The rest of the climb is a scramble.

content.description:
The Patapsco Valley testpiece. Reachy, technical, short, and seldom repeated. Reportedly other parties where attempting this route before Pat and a hold broke off, eventually only yielding to Pat's lanky frame. 

  Start just left of Blue Rose and follow the black streak up and over the roof. No mysteries here just long pulls on sharp small holds.
content.location: The face 2 feet left of Blue Rose and 4 feet right of Ninja.

content.description:
The classic route at Ilchester and maybe in all of Maryland. Packs three cruxes in 30 feet of climbing. 

  A burly first move over the roof to a decent rest jug, tricky jams lead to a stance under the rood and the final "Blue Rose" move over the hang to finish. When you finish look at the large welt on the back of your right hand to find the Rose. 

  A proud on-site for any Baltimore climber. This climb has been led, free-soloed, done blindfolded, aided, and probably climbed more than the all the other climbs in Baltimore combined. If its open hop on!
content.protection: Most often Tr-ed, but is perfectly leadable. The gear while abundant can be strenuous to place and people have taken ground-falls trying to punch through.
content.location: Located on the main face at the obvious crack on the left side of the wall. Start with good finger-locks underneath a small roof.

content.description:
On a small cliff with lots of climbers variations sprout up all over the place. This is a decent variation if you already have the rope up anyway. 

  Climb Blue Rose till under the roof. Step left and pull over the roof at its widest point.
Start at the far right of the lip/rail traverse left to the arete and top out using sharp holds on the arete.
content.location: On the Ilchester Boulder, just to the climbers left of the main cliff

content.description: Starting on the ground is a bit harder than starting on the boulder. Generally follow the left edge and the face just right to the top. A balancy move just off the deck may be the crux.
content.protection: TR from steel anchor. A directional may be needed to keep the rope in line.
content.location: Start at the left edge of the main wall either on top of the boulder or on the ground.

content.description:
Only 10 minutes outside of the beltway, with great routes Ilchester is the center of the universe for Baltimore climbers.  

  There are a few leads, but most climbs are set up via the concrete infused pole on top of the cliff. While exceedingly strong this can get crowded on busy days so some long static rope or webbing is a good idea just in case. Even if you use the pole you need twenty feet or so to put the TR over the edge. 

  The rock is generally sharp, and the well-used holds can be slippery, but often intricate sequences make for great climbing.  

  This is a well used/abused urban crag both by climbers as well as the community so every attempt should be made to keep relations with rangers and locals friendly.
